bestBHT.bht: Jesus testifies to the enduring covenant between God and Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, declaring that these words contain the seed of immortality and hope for resurrection. The resurrection of the dead is a fundamental point of the law, proven by our Lord's reference to the covenant God has with His people, encompassing not only their souls but also their bodies. This solidifies that God is the God of the living, not the dead, as Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob are still living, affirming that the soul does not perish with the body.

Henry Alford: Our Lord here testifies of the conscious intent of God in speaking the words. God uttered them, He tells us, to Moses, in the consciousness of the still enduring existence of His peculiar relation to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.

The words 'I am thy God' imply a covenant; there is another side to them: 'thou art Mine' follows upon 'I am thine.' When God therefore declares that He is the God of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, He declares their continuance, as the other parties in this covenant.
Thus the burden of the Law, 'I AM THE LORD THY GOD,' contains in it the seed of immortality, and the hope of the resurrection.
John Gill: Hence, in opposition to this notion of the Sadducees, the other Jews say, 'Though a man confesses and believes that the dead will be raised, yet that it is not intimated in the law, he is a heretic; since it is a fundamental point, that the resurrection of the dead is of the law.'"

Says R. Simai, from whence is the resurrection of the dead to be proved out of the law? From Exodus 6:4 as it is said, 'I have also established my covenant with them, to give them the land of Canaan: to you' it is not said, but 'to them'; from hence then, the resurrection of the dead may be proved out of the law.

Thus our Lord having to do with the same sort of persons, fetches his proof of the doctrine of the resurrection out of the law, and from a passage which respects the covenant relation God stands in to his people, particularly Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob; and which respects not their souls only, but their bodies also, even their whole persons, body and soul.
John Wesley: God is not the God of the dead, but of the living."
Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob are not dead, but living."
Therefore, the soul does not die with the body.

bhtAttempts.bht: In Matthew 22:32, Jesus affirms the enduring covenant between God and Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, emphasizing that when God declared Himself as their God, He declared their continuance. These words contain within them the seed of immortality and the hope of the resurrection. This notion is foundational, with the resurrection of the dead being a fundamental point of the law. Jesus proves this doctrine by referencing a passage that not only pertains to the souls but also the bodies of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob. Contrary to the Sadducees' belief, God is not the God of the dead, but of the living. Therefore, Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob are not dead, but living, signifying that the soul does not die with the body.

Jesus testifies to the enduring covenant between God and Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, declaring that these words contain the seed of immortality and hope for resurrection. The resurrection of the dead is a fundamental point of the law, proven by our Lord's reference to the covenant God has with His people, encompassing not only their souls but also their bodies. This solidifies that God is the God of the living, not the dead, as Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob are still living, affirming that the soul does not perish with the body.

Jesus confirms the lasting relationship between God and Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob. This covenant implies the continuing existence of these patriarchs, for God is their God. In the words I AM THE LORD THY GOD, lies the promise of immortality and the hope of resurrection. The resurrection of the dead is an essential principle established by the law. Jesus supports this truth by referring to the covenant and affirms that God is not the God of the dead but of the living, indicating that Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob are not dead but alive.

Jesus testifies that when God spoke the words I am thy God to Moses, He did so with the knowledge that His relationship with Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob would endure. This covenant signifies the perpetual existence of these patriarchs, where the Law itself contains the seed of immortality and the hope of resurrection. The resurrection of the dead is a fundamental principle firmly established by the law. Jesus emphasizes this truth by referencing a passage that encompasses not only the souls but also the bodies of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, confirming that God is the God of the living, not the dead.

Jesus affirms that the words I am thy God spoken by God to Moses imply a lasting covenant relationship with Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob. This covenant holds within it the promise of immortality and the hope of resurrection, as the resurrection of the dead is a crucial element of the law. By referring to God's covenant with these patriarchs, Jesus asserts that they are not dead but alive, reinforcing the understanding that the soul does not perish with the body. Thus, God is the God of the living, not the dead.
